lexeme.note: ﻿cf. Skt[i] bhrājate[/i] '(he) shines, beams, glitters', Goth [i]bairhts[/i] ' light, shining'

semantics.meaning: to gleam, glimmer, to be green or yellow

semantics.note: 11th century 'magnificent, beautiful' cf. krasnaja devica ' a fair damsel', prekrasn’Іj ' magnifiscent'

semantics.meaning: darkness, the pupil of the eye, ink

grey, dark grey, blackish, also of dark colors in general

lexeme.note: Probably a loanword from a Mediterranean language

semantics.meaning: purple dye, purple snail, purple clothes
to show, make visible, bring to light, make known

language.name: Modern Greek

language.name: Persian

semantics.note: possibly from association with the yellowing of skin and the bitterness of the gall with the desease jaundice

semantics.meaning: first main room in Roman-style house

lexeme.note: Note also Faliscian arcentelom 'small silver coin', Osc. aragetud, arage 'money': "in theory, the Latin word may have been borrowed into Oscan and Faliscan, but there is no positive proof of this" (MDV).

source.location-within-source: db-44673, APA47, APA47, APA49, APA49, APA63, APA87, APA89, APA91, APA93, APA97, APA99, APA101, APA1…

lexeme.note: Also cānus adj. 'white, esp. of hair' < PItal. *kasno- 'grey' < PIE. *ḱh₁s-no- 'grey'. "Cognate with the word for 'hare' in other IE languages. Lubotsky 1989 connects several other words in initial *ḱ- meaning 'grey': OIr. cíar 'dark-brown' < *ḱh₁-ei-ro-, OIc. hárr, OE. hār 'grey, old' < PGm. *χaira-, RuCS sěrъ, OCz. šěrý, Pl. szary 'grey' < PSl. *xoiro- < *ḱh₁-oi-ro-. Thus, the root ultimately was *ḱh₁-" (MDV)

semantics.meaning: white (especially of hair); white (esp. of hair)
live / bear / be born / fresh (e.g. greens)
live / bear / be born / fresh (e.g. greens)
born; live, be alive; be fresh
be born; shoot, sprout, grow (of seeds and plants)
green, alive, born, give birth, sprout
green, live, alive, raw, give birth
Fire, burn, shine, bright, light, white
